resources.string: Trail Sense uses location data in the background for the sea level pressure calibration in weather monitoring and to provide more accurate sunset alerts. [View Privacy Policy](https://kylecorry.com/Trail-Sense/privacy_policy.html)

Trail Sense is for informational purposes only and the developers make no warranties concerning the accuracy of the information provided by the app, which may further be limited by the quality of your device's sensors and the current environmental conditions.

By using this app, you understand that the developers of Trail Sense cannot and do not assume responsibility for any personal injury, death, property damage, and other dangers associated with activities where you would use Trail Sense.

The developers of Trail Sense are not responsible for how you use the data provided, and what you do with it is done at your own risk. Please do not rely upon it and always have backup plans and gear.

Trail Sense is available under the MIT License
Tips for improving sensor data accuracy
Ensure you have an unobstructed view of the sky, and move away from tall buildings and trees.
Estimate avalanche risks and the height of objects
Tap or hold anywhere to lock or unlock

"Calibration protocol: 
- Set this value to 1. 
- Measure the Trail Sense ruler value corresponding to one unit of a physical ruler. 
- Report the measured value here."
Rotate your phone in a figure 8 pattern or in all directions several times, click %s when finished.
Rotate your phone in a figure 8 pattern or in all directions several times, click %s when finished. \n \nThis alert can be disabled in the app settings.
Enter the current pressure at sea level in hPa
Using a known sea level pressure
Use the temperature in sea level pressure conversions
Show closest beacons on the compass
Trail Sense ran into an error. Please email the developer to get this issue fixed.
A how-to guide for using Trail Sense
%s and all its beacons will be deleted.
%s and all its paths will be deleted.
%s and all its maps will be deleted.
Tap sun or moon for position details
Measure the height of a cliff or drop
Only use this tool when it is safe to do so, and be sure to check what is below the cliff to avoid injury. See the user guide for instructions.
Position solar panels for optimal power production
Place your phone on the face of the solar panel to begin.
Measure the distance from a lightning strike
Bring water to a rolling boil
The strobe feature contains flashing lights, which may be dangerous for some users.
A notification to sync your clock to GPS time
Set the time to %s when the notification arrives

Decimal degrees (ex. 1.00, -2.00)

Degrees decimal minutes (ex. 1°23.12'N, 3°12.1'W)

Degrees minutes seconds (ex. 1°23'12.1"N, 3°12'1.2"W)

UTM (ex. 03T 12345E 67890N)

MGRS (ex. 27PXM 09601 05579)

USNG (ex. 14S NJ 39521 41744)

OSGB (ex. TG 51409 13177)
Power saving mode on, some features may be disabled.
Changes you made will not be saved.
Backtrack is disabled in power saving mode
Disables some features to save power
Requires at least 4 satellites, improves accuracy
High level clouds that form a wavy sheet. The sheet is composed of small dots which almost look two dimensional.
A high cloud that covers the sky. It is transparent and typically causes a halo to form around the sun.
May indicate precipitation in the next %1$d to %2$d hours.
Mid level puffy clouds that look like cotton balls. They are typically white with darker patches below and can be spaced out or sheet-like.
May indicate precipitation or a thunderstorm in the next %d hours.
A mid level cloud that covers the sky. The sun can barely be seen as a bright patch.
May indicate precipitation in the next %d hours.
A mid level cloud that is dark gray and covers the sky. If it is not raining, it may be a stratus cloud.
May have precipitation for the next %d hours.
A low cloud that covers the sky. Objects don\'t cast shadows and it may be foggy.
Low clouds that look like a sheet of cotton balls with small gaps. The color ranges from white to dark gray.
May indicate fair weather for the next %d hours.
Low puffy clouds that look like cotton balls. They are spaced out and are typically white with darker patches below.
May indicate fair weather. If growing taller, may indicate precipitation or a thunderstorm in the next %d hours.
Low puffy clouds that are very tall. They typically have an anvil shape and are dark.
May indicate a thunderstorm in a few minutes.
High wispy clouds that look like tufts of white hair.
Learn how to use Trail Sense\'s features with the user guide. Available at the bottom of the Tools tab.\n\nMore guides will be coming soon.

- Trail Sense respects your privacy and location data never leaves your device

- Trail Sense will never require Internet permission

- View the [privacy policy](https://kylecorry.com/Trail-Sense/privacy_policy.html) (opens in your phone's browser)

- Some features of Trail Sense require access to your location

- Granting the location permission will enable the following features:

	- Navigating to beacons

	- Improved forecast accuracy (not available on all devices)

	- Backtrack

	- Sun and moon times for your current location (sunset alerts may require background location)

- If you choose to not grant the location permission, you can manually enter a location in the Settings > Sensors > GPS calibration menu in Trail Sense.

- After clicking continue, you will be prompted to grant the location permission. Denying this permission will prevent Trail Sense from accessing your location, so a manual location entry is recommended.
Records cell signal at the waypoint. Does not use the Internet.
How to determine the beam distance of flashlights

The accuracy and battery usage of the pedometer is dependent on your device\'s manufacturer and the stride length entered. Try it out at home for a bit to verify battery drain and accuracy before using on the trail.
Map auto-calibrated, please verify its accuracy
The actual frequency may vary as some devices have background limits in place.
Small intervals (under 15 minutes) may cause excess battery drain
Camera permission denied, unable to turn on camera features. You can enable it in settings.
Physical activity permission denied, unable to turn on pedometer features. You can enable it in settings.
Creates a beacon for the last cell signal location
The pressure may differ from that of nearby stations
Use NMEA (satellite) to correct elevations, rather than built-in model
Show on lock screen while navigating
Show on lock screen while open
Forces loading the latest signal strengths
May prevent battery saver apps from completely stopping Trail Sense
The battery log is disabled, history and time until empty may be unavailable. You can re-enable this in settings
Logs battery percentage every hour to estimate time until empty
Your device does not have a %s sensor
Scan a QR code to import
Go outside with an unobstructed view of the sky.
Enable auto adjust location in settings.
Set the location override in settings
Set Trail Sense as not optimized
Enable location or change your location source to \'Device Only\' or \'High Accuracy\'

To measure the height of a target that is %s away:

1. Align the clinometer to the base of the target
2. Tap the screen and hold
3. Realign the clinometer to the top of the target
4. Release to lock and see the height of the target

To measure the distance to a target that is %s tall:

1. Align the clinometer to the base of the target
2. Tap the screen and hold
3. Realign the clinometer to the top of the target
4. Release to lock and see the distance to the target
Enable monitor weather from weather settings
Text is too long, QR code was truncated
Estimated tides may be inaccurate. Please use an official tide table for the exact times.
Predict the temperature at a different elevation

- Designed for hiking, backpacking, camping, and geocaching

- Place beacons and navigate to them

- Follow paths

- Retrace your steps with backtrack

- Plan what to pack

- Be alerted before the sun sets

- Predict the weather

- Use your phone as a flashlight

- And much more!
Walk in a straight line, press stop when you are done

Removing battery restrictions for Trail Sense may improve accuracy.

On most devices, click '%s', then switch to all apps, and switch off battery optimization for Trail Sense.

Visit [Don't kill my app](https://dontkillmyapp.com/) for device specific instructions.
Unable to export map to the chosen file
Use an official tide table to enter reference tides for the length of your trip.
Official tide table websites can be found in the user guide.
The number of high tides per day. Most tides are semidiurnal.
Associated with fair weather, clear skies, and cooler temperatures.
Associated with poor weather, overcast skies, and warmer temperatures.
May indicate fair weather for the next %d hours if it is foggy, otherwise it may indicate precipitation soon.
Prepare for high winds and heavy precipitation.
Prepare for hot temperatures. Take extra precautions against heat exhaustion and heat stroke.
Prepare for cold temperatures. Take extra precautions against hypothermia and frostbite.
All recorded temperatures will be replaced with the calibrated historical temperature.
Temperatures are based on a %d year average of historical data and may not reflect the current weather conditions.

Tap a known location on the map, then enter the real-world coordinates. You can save the calibration by clicking the “Done” button.\n\nExamples of good calibration points are a parking lot, a signage point, a landmark, or a junction along a trail.
The map will align with the top of the screen instead of True North.
Use a photo as a map
Always carry a physical map for backup and verify the accuracy of Trail Sense.
This tool is currently in beta, so please report any issues or feedback to %s.
Cropping the map will still reduce resolution. If you need to crop the map at a high resolution, please use a photo editor app. There are plans to fix this in the future.
Drag the corners of the box to the corners of the map to outline. Cropping will reduce resolution of the map.
Allow %s to set alarms and reminders

This allows %1$s to set exact alarms and reminders, such as sunset alerts. Without this, alarms may not trigger at the correct time.\n\nTo allow, click ‘%2$s’ and enable the setting for allowing alarms and reminders.
Alarms and reminders denied, alerts may be inaccurate.
Sunset alerts may be inaccurate while traveling
Backtrack requires location permission to run
This action will overwrite all of your current data. Please make sure you have a backup before continuing.\n\nOnly select a backup file that you have created with %s and trust.
A backup file will be created containing all your current data. It will include settings, paths, beacons, maps, etc.\n\nThis file is not encrypted. Do not share it with anyone you do not trust.
Restore successful, restarting to apply changes
This backup was created with a newer version of %s. Please update the app and try again.
Record your location and the direction to the destination.
Move at least %s from the first location and record your location and the direction to the destination again.
Choose a known location that you can see and record the direction from where you are to that location.
Choose another known location that you can see and record the direction from where you are to that location.
View nearby beacons and the sun / moon with your camera
Long press a tool to see more options
App settings have been moved to the Tools tab
Your %1$s does not have a built-in %2$s sensor. Unfortunately, this means that some features in %3$s won\’t be available.
Is there a way to fix this?
No, unfortunately this is a hardware feature, so there is nothing that can be done to add it.
My device is new/expensive, why is it missing this sensor?
Some phone manufacturers choose not to add this sensor, even on new or expensive devices. You can get more information by visiting your device manufacturer\’s website or getting in touch with them.
Points to the geographic North Pole using the declination for your location. This will align with most maps.
Points to the magnetic North Pole. This will align with most compasses.
Calibrates whenever there is a GPS fix
Background services could not be restarted. Tap to restart.
Use dynamic colors for cardinal directions
Improves performance at the cost of appearance
Show dial ticks on nearby radar
Your device does not have a compass, but you can still see what direction beacons are.
You can still use the Augmented Reality tool, but it will not be as accurate.
Center the %s in the screen and press \"Calibrate\"
Instead of the compass (avoids magnetic drift)
An error occurred while trying to play audio.
To calibrate the Augmented Reality tool, tap the icon in the top-left of the screen and follow the instructions that appear.
Layer settings may be overridden by guidance, such as the Astronomy guide.

Before each use of the Augmented Reality tool, verify the sun or moon icons are properly aligned to the real world. If not, click the compass icon in the top left of the screen and follow the instructions to calibrate.
Opens the camera when you click the view in 3D button
Turn around by %1$s (%2$s) to return at %3$s
Turn back now to return at %s
Long press bottom navigation or view on tools tab.
Long press bottom navigation or use the Widgets quick action.
Control screen flashlight brightness with volume buttons

This guide is provided for informational purposes only, and neither the author, publisher, or any contributors guarantee its accuracy or suitability for any purpose. By using this guide, you acknowledge that outdoor activities involve risks, and you do so at your own risk, agreeing to hold harmless and indemnify the author, publisher, and any contributors from any claims or damages arising from your use of this guide. Always consult professionals for advice specific to your situation, as this guide does not substitute for professional guidance. Furthermore, be aware that local laws and regulations may affect the legal use of the techniques described herein, and compliance is your responsibility.
Search for survival topics like water, medical, food, weather, shelter, or navigation techniques.
A backup will be created once a day to %1$s. Only the last %2$d backups will be kept.
Unable to create an automatic backup.
Turn automatic backup off and then turn it back on to select a new directory.
Uses the clock to estimate tides. Requires at least one known tide.
Uses the moon\'s position to estimate tides. Requires at least one known tide.
Uses the moon\'s position to estimate tides. Requires the local lunitidal interval and the location.
Uses the moon\'s position to estimate tides. Requires the UTC lunitidal interval.
Uses a built-in tide model to estimate tides for the entered location or your location if none is entered.
View nearby cell towers and signals.

Tower locations are approximated from OpenCelliD, Mozilla Location Service, and FCC Antenna Registrations.\n\n[OpenCelliD Project](https://opencellid.org/) is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/)

This tool is intended for educational purposes only. Always use caution when identifying plants, animals, or mushrooms. Some species may be dangerous or protected. If you are unsure about an identification, consult a professional.

Move into a shady area or block out the sun using a cloth and place paper over your screen so that you can see the map through the paper. Use a pen or pencil to trace the map, but avoid markers or pens that can bleed through the paper.\n\nBottom navigation will be disabled until you turn off trace mode.
A hot and humid climate with significant precipitation throughout the year.
An arid climate with low precipitation and sparse vegetation.
A mild climate with distinct seasons and moderate precipitation.
A cold climate with warm summers, cold winters, and large seasonal changes.
An extremely cold climate with short summers.
The dense foliage may disrupt GPS signals.
There is a short dry season.
There is a dry season. It may contain grasslands with sparse trees.
An extreme lack of precipitation makes for loose terrain and difficulty in finding water.
There is a dry season during the summer.
There is a dry season during the winter.
Some ice may thaw during the summer, but vegetation will be minimal.
The ice does not melt during the year and vegetation is absent.
Plan for hot temperatures all year.
Plan for cold temperatures all year.
Plan for hot temperatures during the summer.
Plan for warm temperatures during the summer.
Plan for cool temperatures during the summer.
Plan for extremely cold temperatures during the winter.
Crashes detected, disabling some features for a few seconds.
Use alarm for turn back alert
Use alarm for water boil timer
Plays a sound even if media and notifications are muted
You can download a digital elevation model in various sizes from %s
PDF maps will be sharper, but performance may be impacted
This tool displays your beacons, paths, and photo maps. It is not a substitute for a dedicated maps application.
Turn on airplane mode to disable all wireless connections.
Turn off Wi-Fi when you aren\'t in range of a Wi-Fi network or don\'t need the Internet.
Turn off Bluetooth when you aren\'t using it.
Turn off NFC when you don\'t need to make contactless payments.
Turn off location when you don\'t need GPS.
Turn on battery saver mode to limit certain phone functions.
Turn on data saver to restrict apps from using mobile data in the background.
Turn on adaptive brightness or dim your screen.
Reduce your screen timeout for when you forget to hit the power button. Turn off always-on display.
Turn on dark theme if your device has an OLED screen.
Restrict background activity for apps that you don\'t need to run in the background.
Adjust system settings to reduce battery usage.
Power off your device, force stop apps, disable or uninstall apps, or disable auto-update/backups.
